headline.main: Nest Labs Stops Selling Its Smoke Detector
headline.print_headline: Nest Labs Stops Selling Its Smoke Detector

docs.abstract: Nest Labs, home automation company recently acquired by Google for $3.2 billion, will halt sales of its smoke and carbon monoxide detector over safety concerns; will also disable feature that allows users to turn it off with a wave; problems are rare blemish for company known for care it puts into products.

docs.snippet: Allerton in the north Bronx has for years been overlooked and mislabeled by city planners and Google, but now residents have set out to get their neighborhood its due....

headline.main: Bronx Neighborhood Fights for Its Spot on the Map
headline.print_headline: Bronx Neighborhood Fights for Its Spot on the Map

docs.abstract: Allerton neighborhood in the north Bronx has, for years, been mislabeled on New York City maps by city planners; residents and local officials have set out to get Allerton its cartographic due, in a campaign that underscores deep pride many New Yorkers take in their neighborhoods.

headline.main: At Google, Bid to Put Its Glasses to Work
headline.print_headline: At Google, Bid to Put Its Glasses to Work

docs.abstract: Google plans to sell its Internet-connected headwear Google Glass to a cautious public later in 2014, but is finding more enthusiastic acceptance in the workplace now; aiming at this market, company is announcing a Glass for Work program to provide additional tools for business users, like tech support, and to explore how to sell Glass to more of them.

headline.main: Earnings and Sales From Google Disappoint
headline.print_headline: Earnings and Sales From Google Disappoint

docs.abstract: Google's first-quarter earnings report surprises Wall Street as its revenue of $15.42 billion falls $100 million short of expectations; company faces problem of Internet users migrating toward mobile devices, but ads on such devices are not as profitable for the company.

headline.main: In Germany, Strong Words Over Google's Power
headline.print_headline: In Germany, Strong Words From Publisher Over Google’s Power

docs.abstract: Mathias Dopfner, chief executive officer of Axel Springer, Germany's largest publisher, suggests that European authorities are colluding with Google to develop a business model that he likens to extortion; comment is made a week after Google chairman Eric E Schmidt mounted spirited defense of Google's digital publishing practices.

byline.contributor: James Kanter contributed reporting from Brussels and Melissa Eddy from Berlin.

docs.lead_paragraph: The largest social sites garner the most visits from mobile devices and from laptop computers and desktop PC’s. Facebook, with a 59.65 percent share in March, dominated traffic from computer users, followed by You Tube (23.02 percent), Twitter (2.29), Google Plus (1.71) and Yahoo Answers (1.07).

docs.snippet: Four leading tech companies are pushing to settle a class-action suit with several noteworthy angles, including questions over employee rights and the death of a programmer who helped set the case in motion....
docs.lead_paragraph: Four leading tech companies are pushing to settle a class-action suit with several noteworthy angles, including questions over employee rights and the death of a programmer who helped set the case in motion.

headline.main: In Silicon Valley Thriller, a Settlement May Preclude the Finale
headline.print_headline: In Silicon Valley Thriller, a Settlement May Preclude the Finale

docs.abstract: Four leading Silicon Valley companies, after years of legal skirmishes, are scheduled to go on trial in May on claims of conspiring not to solicit one another's employees; class-action suit pits software engineers against Google, Apple, Intel and Adobe; case has several noteworthy angles, including questions over employee rights and death of programmer who helped set case in motion.

docs.snippet: An antitrust lawsuit filed by highly paid software engineers shows that the problem of wage theft is not confined to service-sector employees....
docs.lead_paragraph: An antitrust lawsuit filed by highly paid software engineers shows that the problem of wage theft is not confined to service-sector employees.

headline.main: Wage Theft Across the Board
headline.print_headline: Wage Theft Across the Board

docs.abstract: Editorial holds antitrust lawsuit brought by 64,613 software engineers against Google, Apple, Intel and Adobe shows that wage theft is no longer simply a problem for blue collar workers who are forced to work off the clock; calls on Justice Department to pursue tougher cases and settlements against industry collusion and other practices that deny employees their rightful pay.

docs.snippet: Planned new rules would allow an Internet provider to negotiate separately with content companies like Disney or Google and charge for priority service....

headline.main: F.C.C., in a Shift, Backs Fast Lanes for Web Traffic
headline.print_headline: F.C.C., in a Shift, Backs Fast Lanes for Web Traffic

docs.abstract: Federal Communications Commission will propose new rules that allow companies like Disney, Google or Netflix to pay Internet service providers like Comcast and Verizon for special, faster lanes to stream their content to customers; proposed changes would affect what is known as net neutrality--idea that no providers of legal Internet content should face discrimination in providing offerings to consumers, and that users should have equal access to see any legal content they choose.

docs.snippet: The ruling is the strongest statement yet by an antitrust authority against the use of vital patents for mobile digital devices to stymie rivals....

headline.main: Europe’s Antitrust Chief Censures Google’s Motorola Mobility Over Key Patents
headline.print_headline: Europe’s Antitrust Chief Censures Google’s Motorola Mobility Over Key Patents

docs.abstract: European competition commissioner Joaquin Almunia says that Motorola Mobility broke European Union law by trying to wield unfair control over its basic patents for communication technologies used in smartphones and tablet computers; ruling is strongest statement yet by an antitrust authority against use of vital patents for mobile digital devices to hold back rivals.
